pageContext.claim: “We are helping Apple all of the time on TRADE and so many other issues, and yet they refuse to unlock phones used by killers, drug dealers and other violent criminal elements. They will have to step up to the plate and help our great Country, NOW! MAKE AMERICA GREAT AGAIN.”
pageContext.analysis: This is misleading. Apple has refused to break the encryption and unlock two iPhones owned by a Saudi individual implicated in a shooting at a naval base in Pensacola, Fla., saying that opening that door for law enforcement would also open it to bad actors seeking to exploit vulnerabilities. However, Apple has provided gigabytes of information from the suspect's phones, including backups of his data stored on the cloud and transaction data. In a statement, Apple disputed the Trump administration's assertions and said: "We responded to each request promptly, often within hours, sharing information with FBI offices in Jacksonville, Pensacola and New York. The queries resulted in many gigabytes of information that we turned over to investigators. In every instance, we responded with all of the information that we had."
